Command or Action
enable Example: Device> enable
configure terminal Example: Device# configure terminal
ipv6 unicast-routing Example: Device(config)# ipv6 unicast-routing
interface type number Example: Device(config)# interface ethernet 0
ip address ip-address mask [secondary [vrf vrf-name]] Example: Device(config-if)# ip address 192.168.99.1 255.255.255.0
ipv6 address {ipv6-address /prefix-length | prefix-name sub-bits / prefix-length} Example: Device(config-if)# ipv6 address 2001:DB8:c18:1::3/64
Purpose
Enables privileged EXEC mode. Enter your password if prompted.
Enters global configuration mode.
Enables the forwarding of IPv6 unicast datagrams.
Specifies the interface type and number, and enters interface configuration mode.
Specifies a primary or secondary IPv4 address for an interface.
Specifies the IPv6 network assigned to the interface and enables IPv6 processing on the interface.
pageTitle: IPv6 Configuration Guide, Cisco IOS Release 15.2S - IPv6 Addressing and Basic Connectivity [Support] - Cisco
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {52551=0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0, 50178=An IPv6 address prefix, in the format ipv6-prefix/prefix-length, can be used to represent bit-wise contiguous blocks of the entire address space. The ipv6-prefix must be in the form documented in RFC 2373 where the address is specified in hexadecimal using 16-bit values between colons. The prefix length is a decimal value that indicates how many of the high-order contiguous bits of the address comprise the prefix (the network portion of the address). For example, 2001:DB8:8086:6502::/32 is a valid IPv6 prefix., 52899=0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1, 59927=IPv6, formerly named IPng (next generation), is the latest version of the Internet Protocol (IP). IP is a packet-based protocol used to exchange data, voice, and video traffic over digital networks. IPv6 was proposed when the 32-bit addressing scheme of IP version 4 (IPv4) proved to be inadequate to meet the demands of Internet growth. IPv6 is based on IP but with a much larger address space and improvements such as a simplified main header and extension headers. IPv6 is described in RFC 2460, Internet Protocol, Version 6 (IPv6) Specification, issued by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF). Further RFCs describe the architecture and services supported by IPv6.}
textBeforeTable: DETAILED STEPS 6.    ipv6 address {ipv6-address /prefix-length | prefix-name sub-bits / prefix-length} 5.    ip address ip-address mask [secondary [vrf vrf-name]] 4.    interface type number 3.    ipv6 unicast-routing 2.    configure terminal 1.    enable SUMMARY STEPS When an interface in a Cisco networking device is configured with both an IPv4 and an IPv6 address, the interface forwards both IPv4 and IPv6 traffic; that is, the interface can send and receive data on both IPv4 and IPv6 networks. Configuring an Interface to Support the IPv4 and IPv6 Protocol Stacks
textAfterTable: Mapping Hostnames to IPv6 Addresses SUMMARY STEPS 1.    enable 2.    configure terminal 3.    ipv6 host name [port] ipv6-address1 [ipv6-address2...ipv6-address4] 4.   Do one of the following: ip domain name [vrf vrf-name] name ip domain list [vrf vrf-name] name 5.    ip name-server [vrf vrf-name] server-address1 [server-address2...server-address6] 6.    ip domain-lookup DETAILED STEPS   Command or Action Purpose
